title: 107_s1985
content: The "Microcap Fraud Prevention Act of 2001" is the short title of the Act. It includes amendments to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Section 15(b)(4) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include provisions related to orders of the Commission barring or suspending association with a broker or dealer, and requirements for stating material facts in applications, reports, or proceedings. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include provisions related to orders of the Commission barring association with financial regulatory authorities and agencies. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include provisions for orders barring association with financial regulatory authorities or agencies, or engaging in securities, insurance, or banking business, based on violations of laws prohibiting fraudulent, manipulative, or deceptive conduct. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE INVESTMENT ADVISERS ACT OF 1940. Amendment to Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 includes changes related to the suspension of rights for individuals associated with investment advisers and consequences for false or misleading statements made to foreign financial regulatory authorities. The amendment to Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 introduces consequences for individuals who fail to disclose material facts to foreign financial regulatory authorities or violate foreign statutes related to securities, banking, insurance, or commodity trading. The amendment to Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 imposes penalties on individuals who do not disclose important information to foreign financial regulatory authorities or violate foreign laws regarding securities, banking, insurance, or commodity trading. This includes being barred from association with regulated entities or engaging in securities, insurance, or banking activities based on fraudulent, manipulative, or deceptive conduct. The amendment expands the scope of violations under Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 by including paragraph (3) in addition to paragraphs (2) and (6), (8), or (9). The amendment expands violations under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 by adding paragraph (3) to Section 203. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include violations related to false statements or omissions in applications or reports filed with foreign financial regulatory authorities. This expands on violations under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include violations related to securities, banking, insurance, or contracts of sale of a commodity for future delivery traded on or subject to the rules of a contract market or any board of trade. Additionally, individuals who are subject to any order of a State securities commission, State authority supervising financial institutions, State insurance commission, or an appropriate Federal banking agency are also covered under the amendment. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include violations related to securities, banking, insurance, or contracts of sale of a commodity for future delivery. Individuals subject to orders from State securities commissions, State financial institution supervisory authorities, State insurance commissions, or Federal banking agencies may be barred from association with regulated entities or engaging in certain business activities. SEC. 5. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. In Section 15B(c) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, amendments are made regarding Municipal Securities Dealers. The changes include specifying offenses that would disqualify individuals and the actions that would result in being enjoined from certain practices. Amendments are made to various sections of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, including Government Securities Brokers and Dealers and Clearing Agencies, specifying offenses that would result in disqualification and being enjoined from certain actions. Amendments to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 specify disqualifying offenses and actions for individuals, including acts enumerated in specific subparagraphs of section 15(b)(4). SEC. 6. BROADENING OF PENNY STOCK BAR. Section 15(b)(6) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to broaden the scope from penny stocks to noncovered securities and make adjustments to clauses regarding securities offerings and persons subject to orders. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include definitions and criteria for noncovered securities, specifying activities related to noncovered securities offerings and excluding certain individuals or groups as determined by the Commission. Court authority to prohibit offerings of noncovered securities. Section 21(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to give courts the authority to prohibit individuals who violated section 10(b) from participating in offering noncovered securities. The term 'noncovered security' refers to any security not covered in specific sections of the Securities Act of 1933. Participation in an offering of noncovered securities includes various roles like promoter, finder, consultant, or engaging in activities with brokers, dealers, or issuers for the issuance or trading of such securities. Additional activities can be included as specified by the Commission. The term 'noncovered security' refers to any security not covered in specific sections of the Securities Act of 1933. It excludes any person or class of persons that the Commission may exempt by rule, regulation, or order. SEC. 8 amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 by broadening the officer and director bar. SEC. 9 prohibits individuals under a court-ordered bar from serving in certain roles related to noncovered securities.
